abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Development Management Project in
            Mauritania. The objectives of the Development Management
            Project were to support the implementation of the
            Government's Economic and Financial Recovery Program
            (1985-1989) by strengthening weak institutions and building
            administrative capacity in the areas of economic management
            and public service. Bank's performance was not
            satisfactory. Borrower's performance was deficient. The
            key lessons learned were as follows:  i) the difficulty for
            the Bank to be an absentee stakeholder in the process of
            institutional change; (ii) the need for persistent govemment
            commitment to the change agenda and close attention to the
            implementation process by both the Bank and the Borrower;
            (iii) the need to set realistic and monitorable performance
            indicators against which implementation progress can be
            measured; and (iv) the need for the Bank to provide
            frequent, consistent, well-structured and well-organized
            supervision where the emphasis is on providing govemment
            with solid professional advice and technical assistance.

            : Credit 1865 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

abstracts.cdata!:
The Development Management Project seeks
            to finance expertise, equipment and training for key
            institutions and processes in order to: (i) improve core
            government management capabilities within the Presidency;
            (ii) improve economic management; and (iii) improve civil
            service productivity.  It also aims to (iv) strengthen the
            institutional framework for local administration and improve
            the capacity of the Ministry of Interior, Information and
            Telecommunications (MIIT); and (v) create a framework for
            the continued implementation of administrative reform at
            core, sector and local levels.
